bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 20, [1875?]

div1.p: Reed teases Emilie Lawrence about writing. He reiterates his devotion to her, and makes plans to visit her.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 20, [1875?]

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
September 20th

div1.p:
Again
am I the happy recipient of
a dear little letter from
your sweet self- I was
very much interested with
its news, (any event hap-
pening at Murfreesboro
is always doubly dear
to me,) and when I reached
its last sentence, I could
but smile- Perhaps, I should
have cried. And you should
be pleased to see me in
Murfreesboro, because you
are “tired of writing letters”?
You tired of writing, my dar-
ling? And so soon? And
all the Murfreesboro news
right at your pen's point?
Well a day! Then what shall
I, poor mortal, say? Just
think what your feelings
would be, if you had to write
twice the number that you now
write! Only one letter a
week! why I would toss that
off in the twinkling of an
eye, & never feel the labor-
I have just been retrospec-
ting a little, since your letter
came, and I find that, since
my departure from Murfrees-
boro, I have written you
twenty-two letters (this one
included.) Now, at least,
eighteen of these have av-
eraged eight pages each, and
the remainder, at least, 4 pages;
making a grand total of
one hundred & sixty (160) pa-
ges of, love, pure & sub-
lime! The very thought of it
well-nigh overpowers me!
Was ever fond youth more
attentive? Could maiden
require more? Indeed, I
think that I may indulge
in a little flattery, and
call myself a model swain!
'Tis true that the said pages
contain nothing peculiarly
erudite, but still they were
the best the writer could
evolve from out of his concious-
ness, and they bore a more
creditable stamp than that
of erudition- to wit; that
of honesty. In fact, my dar-
ling little Emilie, I never
thought of making any dis-
play, but simply tried to convey
to you my thoughts in lan-
guage plain & unembel-
ished- For I well knew that
you were not going to crit-
icise me. But I'll admit that
I possess one great advan-
tage over you -- pardon my
audacity of speech- It is
this -- whenever I am lack-
ing news to write, I just
throw in a little love, which
answers every purpose- Now
you can't do this! Why, you
shudder at the very idea
of it! Well, never mind- If
I have this advantage, you
regain it as soon as I am
with you, for it then be-
comes your turn to level
those dear little “orbs”
on me, & oh! what sad
havoc thou makest with
my heart! A million, to-
night, for just one glance!
Now I know that your
perceptive faculties are
very acute, & lest you may
miscontrue my words, I de-
sire to say, most emphat-
ically, that I do not indulge
in sentiment simply be-
cause I have nothing else
to write- Ah! no! it is my
heart that bids me do it-
It is the fountain over-
flowing, that cannot be
restrained! And if I had the
most exciting events to nar-
rate, I would toss them
aside, to tell you that I
love you. I sometimes won-
der, if it can be, that you
have grown weary of that
expression! Oh! I trust
not! How dearly I love
to write it! Yes! were this
continent one sheet of pa-
per, I could cover every inch
of it with those three words,
“I love you”! And yet, say
you, I may forget it all, and
find another? well, if this
be so, then we had better
give up life as a bitter
mockery & say that its swee-
test “fruits will turn to
ashes on our lips”! If this
be so, I pronounce my whole
existence as a delusion &
a sham! Emilie, darling,
do you know that I often
wonder what kind of mor-
tal you imagine me to be?
Even in your last letter, you
hinted at the changeable-
ness of men- You seem to
think that the experience of
the world tends to show that
they are only winning wom-
an's love, that they may, the
next moment, trample it un-
der foot- Admit, that this
is the rule; are there no hon-
est exceptions? Are all false?
With all my heart, & in the
name of true manhood, (for
there is such a thing) I re-
pel the assertion that all
are false! It is only a
few dishonest ones who
bring discredit on all-
Oh! my darling, must I tell
you, that I have wept bit-
ter tears over your words!
Once or twice I have well-nigh
despaired of ever convin-
cing you of my sincerity
& have been on the verge of
abandoning my life as
an utter failure! But then
better, nobler thoughts
have gained the ascendan-
cy, & I have said; “by Heaven's
help, I will struggle against
the tide; perhaps, she may
yet, learn than to believe me-
the sky is very dark, but oh!
is not my love sufficient
to sustain my resolutions till
the dawn appears? Yes, if
I can, some day, call her, mine
own, it will more than repay
me, for anything that I can now endure”.
The announcement of Mr
Walter Lassiter's marriage
was a genuine astonish-
ment to me. And yet, when
I came to consider, I saw
nothing to be surprised at-
“They loved” -- That explains
it all- 'Tis you, my little “B.”,
that ought to be astonished.
One of these days there will
be another “Walter” married --
Modesty forbids me to telling
to whom- One year from
this time, I trust that happy
event will occur- I am
coming on very soon to
make all necessary ar-
rangements- By the way,
I cannot say exactly when
I shall appear in Mur-
freesboro- Dr Byrne has
been ordered to Texas
and will leave for that des-
tination, next Thursday or
Friday. Dr Heger, who has
been ordered from St. Paul
Minnesota to this Post, has
not yet arrived- He will
probably report here by
Octr 1st or soon thereafter.
If so, I shall start about
Monday, the 11th of Octr- of
course, I can't state posi-
tively just when I shall
come, but I do not think that
many weeks will elapse be-
fore I shall have the fe-
licity of shaking your
dear little hand-

Till that time, believe
me, as ever,
